Synthesis and Characterization  1-Bromo -3,5-bis(bromomethyl)benzene ( 1)  Over a period of 30  min a solution of PBr 3 (22.2  mL, 63.9  g, 237  mmol) in dry DCM (24  mL) was added to a suspension of alcohol S1[1] (6.00  g, 27.9  mmol) in dry DCM (120  mL). The reaction mixture was stirred 6 h under reflux. After  cooling to room temperature , H2O (24  mL) was added in small portions to the mixture and stirred for 12 h. DCM (240  mL) was added, the phases separated and the organic phase was washed with H2O (3 x 120 mL) and dried over Na 2SO 4. TLC (PE/EtOAc  = 30:1): Rf = 0.30 ( 1). After chromatography (SiO 2, PE/EtOAc  = 30:1) and removal of the solvent by high vacuum , 9.29 g (97 %) of aryl bromide 1 were obtained as a colourless solid.  M.p. = 95¡ãC. 1H NMR  (500 MHz, CDCl 3): ?? (ppm) = 7.45 (d , J = 1.2 Hz, 2H, Ar -4,6-H), 7.34 (s, 1H, Ar -2-H), 4.41  (s, 4H, C H2Br). Analytical data are in accordance to those from lit . After cooling to room temperature, saturated NH 4Cl-solution was added to the  mixture and the mixture extracted with Et 2O (3 x 50 mL). After 1  h this solution was added under argon to a solution of quinone 4 (385 mg, 0.95  mmol) in dry THF (21  mL) and the reaction mixture was stirred 4 hours at room temperature . H2O (1.5  mL), SnCl 2?2H2O (1.11  g, 5.85  mmol) and acetic acid (4.3  mL) was added and the reaction mixture was stirred at RT. After 15  h, DCM (250  mL) was added and the organic phase separated and washed with 3M  HCl (50  mL), 1M HCl (3  x 50 mL) and H 2O (2 x 50 mL).

TLC (PE/EtOAc  =8:1): R f = 0.14 ( 5). Solvents were removed by rotary evaporation and the crude product was purified by column chr omatography (SiO 2, PE/EtOAc  =8:1)  to give 439 mg (58%) of triptycene 5 as a yellow solid.  M.p. = 150¡ãC . 1H NMR (600  MHz, CDCl 3): ?? (9s,10s) -13,16 -bis((3,5 -di(but -3-en-1-yl)phenyl)ethynyl) -9,10-dihydro -9,10-[1,2]benzene -anthracene -2,3,6,7 -tetrayl tetraacetate  (6)  TMSI (1.44  mL, 10.1  mmol) was added to a solution of triptycene 6 (393 mg, 0.50  mmol) in dry degassed DCM (1  mL) at 0¡ãC and afterwards the reaction mixture was stirred at 36¡ãC. After 15  h, acetic anhydride (3.0 mL, 31.8  mmol) was added over a period of 15¡ã min at 0¡ãC and the mixture was stirred at RT. After 24  h, DCM (100  mL) and H 2O (50  mL) was added at 0¡ãC. The organic phase was washed with H 2O (4 x 50 mL) and the combined organic phase was dried over Na 2SO 4. The residue was taken up in DCM (14  mL) and afterwards acetic anhydride (5.5  mL, 58.3  mmol) and pyridine (5.5  mL, 68.2  mmol) were added and the reaction mixture was stirred 15 h at RT. DCM (80  mL) was  added and the organic phase was washed with H2O (4  x 50 mL). After drying over Na 2SO 4 the solvent was removed by rotary evaporation. TLC (DCM; stabilized with amylene): R f = 0.40 ( 6). After column chromatography (SiO 2, DCM; stabilized with amylene) and removal of the solvent by high vacuum gave 191 mg (42%)  of acetate 6 as a yellow solid.  M.p. = 122¡ãC.

(9s,10s) -13,16 -bis((3,5 -di(but -3-en-1-yl)phenyl)ethynyl) -9,10-dihydro -9,10-[1,2]benzene -anthracene -2,3,6,7 -tetraol  (7)  A 0.2M  LiOH -solution (913 ¦ÌL , 183 ¦Ìmol ) was added to acetate 6 (32.6 mg, 36.1 ¦Ìmol) in degassed THF (2.4 mL) and the reaction mixture was stirred at RT. After 15  h, when the mixture has turned blue -green, acetic acid (10.8 ¦ÌL, 189 ¦Ìmol) in degassed H 2O (2.34 mL) was added and the mi xture was stirred at RT.

After 30  min, degassed CHCl 3 (17.5 mL) was added and the orange -colored  phase was transferred with a syringe in to a Schlenk flask  which contained  Na2SO 4. Then ascorbic acid (9.5 mg, 53.9 ¦Ìmol) was added and the reaction mixture was sonicated at 50¡ãC over night . After inert filtration the residue was washed with degassed CHCl 3. The solvent of the yellow solution was removed by applying high vacuum overnight to give 24.3 mg (92%) of oxidation -sensitive tetraol 7 as yellow solid.  1H NM R (300  MHz, CDCl 3): ?? Cage -in-cage compound 10   Hoveyda -Grubbs Catalyst 2nd  Generation  (1 mg, 1.6  ¦Ìmol)  was added in a glove box to a J.Young NMR tube containing a 1.9  mM solution of 9 (10.3  mg, 0.95  ¦Ìmol) in d -TCE (0.5  mL) and after closing the tube the reaction mixture was shaken for 1 min. Then , the tube was stored at RT  under light exclusion . After 36  h, argon was passed through the solution for 30  min. To this solution Hoveyda -Grubbs Catalyst 2nd  Generation  (0.5 mg, 0.8  ¦Ìmol) was added again and the solution stored at RT. After 24  h, ethylvinylether (0.4  mL) was added and the reaction mixture was stirre d at RT. After 10  min, the solution was passed through glass wool and the ether was removed by rotary evaporation. After chromatography (SEC, DCM) d-TCE (1  mL) was added to the first fraction  consisting  cage compound 10. 1H NMR  (400 MHz, Cl 2CDCDCl 2): ?? Todate, only afew examples areknown ,inwhich DCC was used tobuildupamolecu lardefined butlargerproduct that was chem-ically transferr edtoamore stable congener inasecond(irreversible )step. Here, we present ananomet er-sized[8+12]boron icester cage containing 48periphera ltermi-nalalkene units whic hallows toput ahydrocarbon exo-skeleton around thecage viaalkene metathes is.

General Remarks  All reagents and solvents were obtained from Fisher Scientific, Alfa Aesar, Sigma -Aldrich or VWR and were used without further purification unless otherwise noted. For thin layer chromatography silica gel 60 F 254 plates from Merck were used and examined under UV -light irradiation (254  nm and 365  nm). Flash column chromatography was performed on silica gel from Sigma -Aldrich (particle size: 0.04 -0.063  mm) using petroleum ether, ethyl acetate and dichloromethane . Size Exclusion Chromatography (SEC) was performed on BioBeads S -X1 from Bio -Rad Laboratories, Inc. using dichloromethane as solvent. Melting points (not corrected) were measured with a B¨¹chi Melting Point B -540. IR-Spectra were recorded on a Ge ATR crysta l with a Bruker Lumos spectrometer or on a Jasco FT/IR -4100 spectrometer.  NMR spectra were taken on Bruker Avance III 600 (1H NMR: 600  MHz; 13C NMR: 151  MHz), Avance III 500 (1H NMR: 500  MHz; 13C NMR: 125 MHz), Avance III 400 (1H NMR: 400 MHz; 13C NMR: 100  MHz), Avance DRX 300 and Avance III 300 (1H NMR: 300 MHz, 13C NMR: 75 MHz) spectrometer at 298 K, unless otherwise mentioned. Chemical shifts ( ¦Ä) are reported in parts per million (ppm) relative to traces of CHCl 3 (¦ÄH = 7.26 ppm, ¦ÄC = 77.2  ppm) or Cl2CDCDCl 2 (¦ÄH = 5.96  ppm, ¦ÄC = 77.2  ppm) in  the corresponding deuterated solvent. HRMS experiments were carried out on a Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance (FTICR) mass spectrometer solariX (Bruker Daltonik GmbH, Bremen, Germany) equipped with a 7.0 T  superconducting magnet and interfaced to an Apollo II Dual ESI/MALDI source or on a Bruker Autoflex Speed MALDI -TOF mass spectrometer with DCTB (trans -2-[3-(4-tert-butylphenyl) -2-methyl - 2-propenylidene]malononitrile) as matrix.  Elemental analysis was per formed by the Microanalytical Laboratory of the University of Heidelberg using an Elementar Vario EL machine.
